title: (x) Serif face in Dutch translation of Dante's Divine Comedy - Adobe Garamond {Jan E}
content:
Hi all,

Here’s an excerpt of a typeface which I can’t identify. Sometimes I think it’s a kind of Garamond, but the j’s are too different. Does anyone recognize this font?

It’s a scan from a Dutch translation of Dante’s Divine Comedy, by Primavera Pers, Leiden, published in three parts around 2000.

Thanks in advance.

Marcel

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [scan\_dante.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20071225133155/http:/typophile.com/files/scan_dante.gif) | 89.11 KB |

 [‹ "design your board" classic serif face](http://web.archive.org/web/20071225133155/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40282 "Go to previous forum topic") [AdiHaus ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071225133155/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40285 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Marcel-

comments.content: The “J” seems to match up with ITC Galliard. In fact, many of the roman letters do. But the Italic is a whole nother story... Perhaps the Dutch Foundry could be of some help to ID it if no one else chimes in. Sorry, I can’t be more helpful.

I think it’s Garamond Amsterdam, which would explain “Dutch”; it also has a similar italic, but not quite right, I think.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/garamont-amsterdam/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071225133155/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/garamont-amsterdam/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/garamont-amsterdam/")
Isn’t this just Adobe Garamond? I think it looks a lot like it.

I second Jan’s comment.

Garamont Amst is much too close to the monotype Garamond to be the culprit.

BTW. I’ve always loved the monotype version (although not a real Garamond), especially the italics with all its quirks. I don’t see around much anymore... pity.

yep, adobe garamond, definitely

oh, and i also love the monotype version, achillesg
Thank you for your fast replies, I thought the j’s were too different, but you’re right!
